page.title: 02HISTORY OF HAMPTON,HERNE BAY
page.content: In 1800 the small area of land contained in this Block was more extensive than it is today by about 30 acres. In 1800 the area was used for farmland with a large brick farmhouse and nearby were several wooden huts occupied by fishermen who also had a reputation as smugglers. This hamlet of Hampton also possessed a public house called the Beehive. In 1866 the Hampton Oyster Company was opened by the Mayor of London. This was to rival the Whitstable Companies. A pier was built so that boats connected with the trade could load and unload. The Company was quite profitable for about 15 years but then the operations were moved to Faversham. It is thought that the building of the pier caused erosion of the land on its westward side and 30 acres containing the old buildings were worn away.
